Prompt Basics.title: Knowledge check
Prompt Basics.intro: Make sure you can scope prompts, set expectations, and reinforce QA steps before moving on.
instructions: Choose the best answer for each question.
Score at least 3/3 before you move to the next track.

questions.prompt: What is the primary role of the planner step in the planner → actor → reviewer loop?

options.text: Generate the final deliverable
options.feedback: The actor produces the deliverable once the plan is agreed.

options.text: Frame the task, constraints, and desired outputs
options.feedback: Planners shape the problem, guardrails, and success targets so the actor can execute.

options.text: Sign off on legal compliance
options.feedback: The reviewer verifies compliance after the actor responds.

questions.prompt: Which prompt ingredient prevents the model from drifting into the wrong tone or persona?

options.text: Acceptance criteria
options.feedback: Acceptance criteria describe outputs; tone comes from role or persona prompts.

options.text: Role or voice instruction
options.feedback: Explicit voice instructions anchor tone and perspective.

options.text: Fallback escalation note
options.feedback: Escalation instructions help with risk, not tone.

questions.prompt: When should you recap the draft prompt back to stakeholders before shipping?

options.text: Only when they request a change
options.feedback: Proactive recaps prevent rework and surface misalignments early.

options.text: After the first live run in production
options.feedback: Wait until production and you're reacting to failures instead of preventing them.

options.text: Before the first production run, while you're still in review
options.feedback: Recapping while still in review keeps the loop tight and avoids missed constraints.

scoring.guidance: Mark the enablement tracker as complete once you hit the passing score.
actions: Log the completion in your enablement tracker.
Capture any confusing items in the backlog for future updates.

Memory & Privacy.title: Memory governance quiz
Memory & Privacy.intro: Check that you can spot unsafe memory usage and enforce retention policies.
instructions: Select one answer per question and submit to see guidance.
Follow remediation actions when you miss a question.

questions.prompt: Which data class must never be stored in persistent memory according to the guide?

options.text: Meeting agendas shared with the team
options.feedback: Agendas are generally safe once sanitized.

options.text: Customer payment information
options.feedback: Payment and other regulated data classes must stay out of persistent memory.

options.text: Public marketing copy
options.feedback: Public information can be retained as long as it is current.

questions.prompt: What is the first step when you discover memory storing restricted transcripts?

options.text: Purge the memory slot immediately and open an incident ticket
options.feedback: You must remediate the slot right away and alert the incident path for review.

options.text: Notify the customer success team within 48 hours
options.feedback: CS should know, but only after you have already contained the issue.

options.text: Export the memory data for offline audit
options.feedback: Exporting creates more copies of restricted data and violates policy.

questions.prompt: Which retention control keeps memory outputs aligned with policy?

options.text: Weekly desk checks from legal counsel
options.feedback: Counsel is involved for escalations, but regular QA sits with operators.

options.text: Automated reminders to submit updates
options.feedback: Reminders are helpful, yet they do not verify content directly.

options.text: Monthly QA spot checks with a purge + rehydrate cycle
options.feedback: Spot checks with purge/rehydrate keep data current and compliant.

scoring.guidance: Record the score in the memory governance log. Capture any remediation you assign.
actions: If you miss anything, rerun the Memory & Privacy drills with your team.
Escalate confirmed policy gaps to the data protection officer.

Project Folders Setup.title: Operational readiness check
Project Folders Setup.intro: Verify you can launch and maintain the shared folder structure without missing governance steps.
instructions: Answer each scenario with the action that keeps the folder healthy.
Aim for 3/3 to progress. Use the remediation actions if you miss a step.

questions.prompt: A teammate moves draft deliverables into 50_final without review. What do you do first?

options.text: Move the files back and log the deviation in the changelog
options.feedback: Restoring order and logging the issue protects audit trails.

options.text: Notify leadership but leave the files in place
options.feedback: Leadership should know, yet you must fix the structure before notifying.

options.text: Archive the entire folder
options.feedback: Archiving is too heavy-handed and hides the audit trail.

questions.prompt: Where should reusable prompts and instructions live so the team can find them later?

options.text: 30_working-drafts
options.feedback: Working drafts rotate frequently and are not the source of truth.

options.text: 20_prompts with a README linking to the prompt library
options.feedback: 20_prompts plus the library link keeps the assets curated and discoverable.

options.text: 90_archive
options.feedback: Archive is for retired material only.

questions.prompt: How often should the changelog be updated for active projects?

options.text: At least weekly with owner, action, and affected path
options.feedback: Weekly updates keep stakeholders aligned and audits clean.

options.text: Only when major milestones finish
options.feedback: Waiting for milestones creates blind spots for small but important changes.

options.text: Once per quarter during retrospectives
options.feedback: Quarterly updates are too infrequent for active delivery.

scoring.guidance: Log completions in the enablement tracker and store the score alongside the changelog.
actions: If you miss a question, schedule a 15-minute retrain using the Acceptance checklist.
Log completions and misses in the enablement tracker.
